description:
CHaMP is designed as a Columbia River basin-wide habitat status and trends monitoring program built around a single protocol with a programmatic approach to data collection and management (RM&E Workgroup 2010). CHaMP will result in the collection and analysis of systematic habitat status and trends information that will be used to assess basin-wide habitat conditions. When coupled with biological response indicators, this status and trends information will be used to evaluate habitat management strategies. This program will be integrated with ongoing Pacific Northwest Aquatic Monitoring Program (PNAMP) recovery planning efforts and will be part of the collaborative process across Columbia Basin fish management agencies and tribes and other state and federal agencies that are monitoring anadromous salmonids and/or their habitat. The implementation of CHaMP will characterize stream responses to watershed restoration and/or management actions in at least one population within each steelhead and spring Chinook Major Population Group (MPG) which have, or will have, “fish-in” and “fish-out” monitoring (identified in RPA 50.6), thereby meeting the requirements of RPA 56.3, RPA 57, and RPA 3. CHaMP was designed to deliver trends in habitat indicators and requires that monitoring occurs for three cycles of a sampling panel, at least 9 years.

The Tucannon CHaMP status and trends domain includes the mainstem Tucannon and a short distance up several tributaries, targetting the Chinook population and covering the most important domain of the Steelhead (Snake River DPS) Tucannon River Population.  The Tucannon will receive a significant amount of treatment over the coming years through restoration work by the Snake River Salmon Recovery Board; a system of treatment/control groups has been set up yielding a set of tiny treatment/control strata as part of the CHaMP study design.  The design splits the sampling into these paired groups and to “mainstem” and “tributary” groups.

The standard valley class stratification was abandoned for Tucannon partly because all sites fell into the depositional stratum, and partly because of the treatment-control design imposed.  As well, the private/public split was abandoned given the small number of choices in most of the treatment/control strata and the small target frame.

2017 sample design notes:

8/4/17: CBW05583-519039 was moved from RP 2 Trt Reach 8-Treatment back to Annual Trt Reach 8-Treatment and block counts were adjusted.

CBW05583-339839 was moved from RP3 Treatment Reach 2 control back to Annual Treatment Reach 2 Control and block counts were adjusted.

These sites were previously moved to RP blocks due to reduced 2017 funding but there is now funding to sample them.  

 

7/28/17: WDFW requests sampling of all sites along the mainstem.  This has triggered shifting of 4 sites to the RP1 panel to allow sampling in 2017.  These will be added to a new block and refiled at the end of the year back into their native panels. Use Orders were all 1 for moved sites--these were assigned 1,2,3, and 4 in the new block. 

CBW05583-018303 shifted from RP2 Treatment Reach 4-Control. 

CBW05583-214475 shifted from RP3 Mainstem 

CBW05583-051659 shifted from RP2 Treatment Reach 2 Control

CBW05583-465355 shifted from RP3 Treatment Reach 2 Treatment

6/26/17: AEM Update #2:

Site CBW -460671 was moved from Rotating Panel 3-Treatment Reach 4, Use Order 1 to Annual-AEM-Treatment Reach 4 Control block to become available for 2017 sampling.  It should be refiled after the field season. Block counts were moved accordingly.

6/22/17:

AEM Update:  

  • CBW-427903 was moved from RP3-Treatment Reach 4-Treatment to Annual-Treatment Reach 4-Treatment to allow AEM sampling.  Use order 1 in both blocks (old and new)
  • CBW-079743 was moved from RP3-Mainstem to Annual-Mainstem to allow AEM sampling.  Use order was changed from 2 to 1.  Block counts adjusted for all 4 blocks affected by this change. sites should be moved back into original panels when 2017 sampling is complete.

 

Sampling frequency was reduced in the Tucannon in 2017 from 25 to 18 sites by changing most of the annual sites to rotating panel sites.  Specifically,

CBW -481459 was moved from annual to RP1

CBW-386091 from annual to RP2

CBW-339839 from annual to RP3

CBW-007039 from annual to RP1

CBW-519039 from annual to RP2

​Block effort was changed accordingly, along with use orders.  Tributary site 310143 will also not be sampled this year (RP1-Tributary block effort reduced by 1).

 

 

2016 sample design notes:

Refiled sites moved for pre-restoration sampling in 2015: ​​​CBW05583-072139 (treatment reach 2-control): Changed from Use Order 2 RP3 back to Use Order 2 Annual.

CBW05583-214475 (mainstem): Use Order 8 Annual Mainstem changed back to RP3 Use Order 1 for mainstem.   

There are no design changes for 2016 but a new design was created to track AEM updates needed in cm.org.  

  • CBW 384819 was refiled to RP3 mainstem, Use Order 4.  This was put into a special block in 2015 for AEM sampling.
  • CBW-100223 from RP2, Treatment Reach 4-Control was moved to an AEM-specific block for 2016 sampling (out of normal rotation) Use order was from 1 to 1.
  • CBW-214911 from RP2 Treatment Reach 8-Control was moved to an AEM-specific block for 2016 sampling (out of normal rotation), Use order was from 1 to 1.

 

5/1 waiting for additional feedback from Hill re: 2015 refiling of his specific requests.

2015 sample design notes:

All core CHaMP designs were updated to accommodate effort that will go towards the 10% repeat design for CHaMP.   The design update will result in 3 annual sites from the active design (e.g. 2014) and move one to each rotating panel.  This will result in a net freeing of 2 visits each year that can be used to revisit 2 sites.  This change preserves the annual sites within the design and adjusts the frequency of sampling.  2 sites slated for sampling in the current year (e.g. 2015) will be randomly selected for repeat sampling.​

The following three sites were selected by ELR (Hill) to be removed from the Annual panel and shifted to each of the rotating panels. Changes made to accommodate repeat sampling effort:​

CBW05583-169855, Treatment Reach 5-Treatment moved to rotating panel 1
CBW05583-427903, Treatment Reach 4-Treatment moved to rotating panel 3
CBW05583-432587, Treatment Reach 6-Control moved to rotating panel 2

Additional changes requested by Hill in 2015:

​​​CBW05583-072139 (treatment reach 2-treatment): Change from Annual to PY3

CBW05583-214475 (mainstem): Change from PY3 to Annual, use order became 1, even though original GRTS order puts it farther down in the list.  had to put it at 1 to get sampled in 2015.

Site 274303 was not sampled as an AEM annual in 2014 and was therefore moved back into RP3.  This change will also be made in the 2014 design. 

block orders also adjusted for all of these changes. 

 

 

2014 sample design notes: 

No changes from 2013.

6/24/2014: Two sites from the Tucannon CHaMP design changed Blocks to accommodate AEM sampling in 2014.  CBW05583-274303 was originally allocated to Rotating Panel 3-Treatment Reach 2-Control, Use order 1 and was moved to Annual AEM-Treatment Reach 2-Control. Block allocation of Rotating Panel 3-Treatment Reach 2-Control changed from 1 to 0.  

CBW274303 was originally allocated to Rotating Panel 3-Mainstem, Use order 3 and moved to Annual-Mainstem, Use order 1. Block allocation for Rotating Panel 3-Mainstem changed from 4 to 3. 

2012 sample design notes:

The basic design of the Tucannon remained the same as 2012 in 2013.  There were minor adjustments to site stratum assignments as additional treatment/control groups were established, converting from mainstem to treatment/control.

2013 sample design notes

​​In 2013, the strata names were updated to exclude specific treatment and control pairs by to more general 'Treatment 1 vs. Control' pairs of reference reaches.  E.g. Treatment Reach 1-Treatment 1 stratum became Treatment Reach 1-Treatment.

 Legacy sample GRTS Input file: None--no legacy sites used in 2011 Tucannon design.

targetPopulation:
2015, 2016, 2017: There were no updates to the frame.

2014 Frame Updates:

There were no updates to the frame in 2014.  

2013 Frame Updates:

There were no frame updates made in 2013, although some strata names changed. The spatial extent of the strata did not change.

2012 Frame Updates:

Frame was updated to include Treatment 6-Control, Treatment 6-Treatment, Treatment 7-Control, Treatment 7-Treatment, Treatment 8-Control and Treatment 8-Treatment reaches.  The full extent of the frame did not change, just the strata within the frame.

2011 Frame Description:

The default CHaMP target frame (domain of inference) is represented by the population of all stream reaches that meet the following criteria:

  • Strahler order > 1
  • Wadeable (Strahler order > 5)
  • Perennial (as defined by NHDPlus hydrography)
  • Downstream of permanent natural barriers < 12 %
  • Downstream of permanent human-made barriers
  • Accessible to adult and juvenile TRT populations as represented by the NHDPlus hydrography?

 

CHaMP will be used to determine the effectiveness of instream habitat complexity restoration methods (e.g., LWD installation) and to a lesser extent reconnection of the stream to the floodplain (e.g., levee setbacks). To maximize the ability to determine the effectiveness of restoration actions, the domain of inference in the Tucannon River to include only the spring Chinook domain as defined in the subbasin plan (SRSRB 2011). This restricted domain of inference was established because the focus of restoration efforts in the Tucannon River are targeted at spring Chinook (ADEQ 2011) and the SRSRB is required to demonstrate the effectiveness of habitat restoration as part of the BiOP. 

Treatment and control areas were used as strata. This ensured that CHaMP sites were allocated in treatment and control areas throughout the domain of inference. This approach will allow for effectiveness monitoring of the restoration actions. A small sampling effort was put into 'mainstem' and 'tributary' strata for status and trends monitoring of non-restoration areas within the domain.  

Tucannon Frame File: 

TucannonFrameFile.zip
title: Tucannon Watershed Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) in 2017
